title: Borrowers brace for higher mortgage repayments | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Homeowners were given a warning from the Reserve Bank that interest hikes could be coming in 2026.  Reserve Bank governor Michele Bullock has all but confirmed Australia's cash rate will not drop further as the "risks to inflation have tilted to the upside". After keeping rates on hold at 3.6 per cent for the third consecutive meeting, the RBA governor said the central bank will either increase rates, or keep them steady at the board's upcoming meetings in 2026.  Treasurer Jim Chalmers said "a lot of Australians would have wanted some more rate relief, but they wouldn't have expected it."  If the cash rate was increased, it's highly likely banks and lenders will pass the hike on to customers, pushing up home loan repayments.  Money markets are now fully pricing in a rate hike by next June with an outside chance of one as early as February.  HSBC's chief economist for Australia and New Zealand, Paul Bloxham, agrees the central bank's next move is up.  #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-12-09/rba-interest-rate-decision-december-2025/106120130  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Australia, US to "expand" and "strengthen" AUKUS security and submarine deal | ABC NEWS
description: The Trump administration has again declared it's going "full steam ahead" with the AUKUS submarine pact after a high level meeting in Washington DC. Defence and foreign affairs ministers gathered in the US capital for their first meeting under the second Trump administration with military cooperation and the nuclear powered submarines plan high on the agenda. Foreign affairs correspondent Stephen Dziedzic reports. title: How a 'broken' domestic gas system is contributing to high electricity prices | The Business
description: High electricity prices are a major driver of inflation and a huge burden on business. Underpinning this is a shortage of domestic gas. The stakes couldn't be higher for the federal government to pick the right solution with the imminent release of its long awaited review into the gas market. Lead analyst for Australian gas at the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA), Josh Runciman joined The Business to discuss the situation the Australia's domestic gas market is in now. He says in a word, Australia's east coast gas market is broken. He says there are a couple of factors that have contributed to the situation we have now, which include the cheap reserves that have powered eastern Australia for the last 50 years, are gone effectively.   The reserves in offshore Victoria are now in decline. However, he says the key factor that has led to Australia's gas shortage problem was the start of the LNG export industry. He says, "ten years ago, Santos started exporting from the Gladstone LNG facility and really ever since then, Santos has effectively been taking gas out of the domestic market to meet their export contracts... So that company effectively made a private decision to build an LNG export facility that was larger than they had reserves for, and we've been paying for it ever since." #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. It's news when you want it, from Australia's most trusted news organisation. title: Toyah's Murder: Sentence delivered for 'opportunistic' murder | The Case Of...
description: Justice Lincoln Crowley delivered his sentencing remarks only a day after jurors found Rajwinder Singh guilty of Toyah Cordingley's murder, outlining a possible explanation for what happened the day she died. In this episode, Christopher Testa and Stephen Stockwell recap the key moments from Justice Crowley's remarks, as well as the victim impact statements from members of Toyah's family.  If you have any questions you'd like Chris and Stocky to answer in future episodes, please email thecaseof@abc.net.au The Case Of is the follow-up to the hit podcast Mushroom Case Daily, and all episodes of that show will remain available in the back catalogue of The Case Of.

title: TPG boss reveals second death with possible links to Triple Zero failure | ABC NEWS
description: TPG Telecom has revealed a second death possibly linked to outdated software on some Samsung devices that stops customers from connecting to Triple Zero on the defunct 3G network. The incident was reported in another federal parliament grilling of telco bosses, which customer advocates say left many questions unanswered. title: Victorian government makes historic apology to Aboriginal people | ABC NEWS
description: The Victorian government has made a historic apology to Aboriginal Victorians in one of the first steps to follow the state's treaty agreement. The apology for all past laws and practices that harmed Aboriginal people fulfills a recommendation from the state's truth-telling inquiry, the Yoorrook Justice Commission. It was delivered in a special sitting of Victorian parliament, but failed to win the support of the state opposition. title: Fracked gas to enter NT energy market by 2026 to ‘keep the lights on’ | ABC NEWS
description: The Northern Territory government is hailing a new agreement which will see fracked gas flow into the NT energy market from next year as a deal that will "save the territory". title: IAEA says Ukraine's bombed Chernobyl shelter no longer blocking radiation | The World | ABC News
description: The protective shield that covers the Chernobyl nuclear reactor is no longer providing its main containment function of blocking radiation, after damage from a drone strike in February. The International Atomic Energy Agency says repairs were "essential" to "prevent further degradation" of the nuclear shelter. Ukraine has blamed Russia for the strike on the nuclear plant. The Kremlin has denied those claims. Robert Kelley, nuclear engineer and former IAEA inspector spoke to The World's Girish Sawlani about the seriousness of the damage sustained. title: 'Act of forgery': FIFA accuses Malaysia of faking foreign players' eligibility | ABC News
description: Global football's governing body FIFA has found Malaysia "cheated" by forging documentation to improperly naturalise foreign players from South America and Europe. While the international players' union says the seven players are "victims", FIFA has imposed a 12-month suspension on them. FIFA has also lodged criminal complaints in five countries and launched its own investigation into the Football Association of Malaysia. ABC journalist Max Walden spoke to the World's Girish Sawlani about the impact the scandal has had on Malaysian football.
